Award.AbstractNarration:
CIF: Large: Collaborative Research: Controlled Sensing, and Distributed Signal Processing and Decision Making in Networked Systems

PIs: Demosthenis Teneketzis (Michigan) and Venugopal Veeravalli (Illinois)

Abstract:

Many modern technological systems are networked systems. Networked systems are informationally decentralized, comprise many nodes carrying disparate information, and are subject to constraints on energy, data storage and computational capabilities. This research project entails a comprehensive study of fundamental issues that arise in networked systems, pertaining to controlled sensing, distributed signal processing, and distributed decision making, whose resolution will lead to substantial improvements in network performance. The project aims at (i) improving our understanding of the role of information in sensing, signal processing and decision making for networked systems under various architectures, in controlled and distributed settings; (ii) improving our understanding of coordination of networked systems, by evaluating the performance of the different architectures; and (iii) generating novel algorithms that will lead to networked systems that exhibit superior performance over current ones. The problems underlying these objectives cannot be adequately tackled using standard approaches in signal processing or stochastic and deterministic control theory. The investigators use key tools from stochastic optimization, distributed computation, and probability theory to develop novel methodologies that address the underlying challenges.

This project has broader impact on several fronts. It provides systematic design methodologies that are essential in many modern networked systems, and in particular, in systems for environmental (e.g., soil moisture) monitoring with distributed sensors. In addition, the research output of this project is expected to be useful to NSF's NEON program, to NASA's earth science program, and to NOAA's monitoring program. The research activities are expected to have an impact on technology transfer and graduate education through course development and training of students, with a special emphasis on including women and under-represented minority students through a strong mentorship program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of the grant was to undertake a comprehensive study of fundamental issues that arise in informationally decentralized networked systems, (e.g. communication, sensor and transportation networks; climate, soil-moisture, water-quality, surveillance, energy, and electronic commerce systems, as well as the internet), pertaining to controlled sensing, distributed signal processing, and distributed decision making. Research efforts were aimed at: (1). Improving our understanding of the role of information in controlled sensing, distributed signal processing, and distributed decision making; (2). Improving our understanding of how to organize/coordinate informationally decentralized networked systems by evaluating the performance of various architectures for controlled sensing, distributed signal processing and distributed decision making; and (3). Generating novel algorithms for controlled sensing, distributed signal processing, and distributed decision making whose implementation within the context of various architectures will lead to networked systems with superior performance as compared with the existing ones.

Our research results met the above-stated objectives. Below we present the key results of our research and their implications. They are: (1). The discovery of a methodology that results in better performance of surveillance systems, monitoring systems, and multiple access communication networks.  (2). The discovery of a methodology that results in efficient solutions to trading problems over the internet, and to a better understanding of cyber-security problems. (3). The discovery of resource allocation mechanisms that result in efficient traffic regulation in the internet. (4). The discovery of incentive mechanisms that enhance the security of networked systems, such as inter-connected communities. (5). The design of mechanisms/auctions that ensure reliability, sustainability, and price efficiency in the restructured electricity industry. (6). The discovery of sensor scheduling algorithms for soil-moisture estimation. These algorithms significantly increase the wireless sensors' life and secure high quality soil-moisture estimation. (7). The design of mechanisms for efficient incorporation of wind energy into the smart grid. Our mechanisms perform better than the ones currently used in the U.S. and Europe.

In summary, the research supported by this grant contributed to the improvement in performance of several important modern technological systems. Furthermore, our basic research results significantly contributed to the advancement of the state of the art in decentralized decision making under uncertainty. Our results solved a long-standing problem in decentralized stochastic control. Our results also present a methodology for solving a broad class of decentralized decision making problems, with strategic or no-strategic decision makers, that were previously unsolved.
